description: From Middle English grubben, grobben, from Old English *grubbian, from Proto-West Germanic *grubb-, from Proto-Germanic *grubb- (compare Middle Dutch grobben (“to scrape, scramble, grab”), Old High German grubilōn (“to dig, search”), German grübeln (“to meditate, ponder”)), from Proto-Germanic *grub- (“to dig”) (see *grabaną).

The noun sense of "larva" (c. 1400) may derive from the notion of "digging insect" or from the possibly unrelated Middle English grub (“dwarfish fellow”). The slang sense of "food" is first recorded 1659, and has been linked with birds eating grubs or with bub (“drink”)."

entries.meaning: (countable) An insect at an immature stage of its life cycle.
(Australia, slang) A despicable person; a lowlife.
(obsolete) A short, thick man; a dwarf.
examples: John Romane, a short clownish grub, would bear the whole carcase of an ox, yet never tugged with him.

verbs.description: grub (third-person singular simple present grubs, present participle grubbing, simple past and past participle grubbed)

entries.meaning: To scavenge or in some way scrounge, typically for food.
(transitive, intransitive) To dig; to dig up by the roots; to root out by digging; often followed by up.
examples: to grub up trees, rushes, or sedge

entries.meaning: (slang, dated, transitive) To supply with food.
